event: First permanent settlements appear in present-day Panama by pre-Columbian indigenous peoples.
Rodrigo de Bastidas becomes the first European to explore the Panamanian coast.
Christopher Columbus explores Panama during his fourth voyage.
First permanent European settlement established at Santa María la Antigua del Darién.
Vasco Núñez de Balboa crosses the Isthmus of Panama and discovers the Pacific Ocean.
Panama becomes the seat of the Real Audiencia of Panama under Spanish rule.
Panama declares independence from Spain and joins Gran Colombia.
After breakup of Gran Colombia, Panama remains a department of Colombia.
Mallárino–Bidlack Treaty signed between U.S. and New Granada (Colombia), granting U.S. transit rights.
Panama Railway completed across the isthmus, first transcontinental railroad.
French attempt to build Panama Canal under Ferdinand de Lesseps begins, but fails by 1889.
With U.S. support, Panama declares independence from Colombia; Hay–Bunau-Varilla Treaty signed with U.S.
U.S. begins construction of the Panama Canal.
Panama Canal officially opens under U.S. control.
Military coup brings General Omar Torrijos to power.
Torrijos–Carter Treaties signed, agreeing to transfer control of Panama Canal to Panama by 1999.
U.S. invades Panama to remove General Manuel Noriega from power.
Panama assumes full control of the Panama Canal from the U.S.
Panama Papers leak exposes global tax evasion linked to Panamanian law firm Mossack Fonseca.
COVID-19 pandemic severely impacts Panama’s economy and healthcare system.
